awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Development of Multi-mode Integral Field Units for Magellan (IFU-M)
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the main ways that astronomers study the universe is by splitting the telescope light from celestial sources into its component colors.  This technique, known as spectroscopy, can often reveal the underlying processes that govern stars, galaxies and the like.  A traditional astronomical spectrograph obtains color information at the expense of imaging.  However, a modern Integral Field Unit (IFU) spectrograph is able to do both.  An IFU obtains an image and a spectrum at each pixel of the image of an astronomical source.  The resulting data cube can be studied to determine the spatial distribution of light across a single extended object, or it can be used to study multiple stars or galaxies at once.   This project will support the development of an IFU system for the Magellan/Clay telescope at the Las Campanas Observatory.  When completed, this instrument will enable a wide range of investigations into topics from the formation of young stars to the dynamics of gas outflows in distant galaxies.  In addition to providing a new tool for research, this project will also serve as an essential training opportunity for students and early career scientists. Live feeds from the telescope will be used in conjunction with undergraduate classes.  

This project builds upon the previous MRI award, 0923160 (PI: Mateo), which funded the development of the Michigan/Magellan Fiber System (M2FS) spectrograph.   The M2FS system actually consists of two high-performance optical spectrographs that deliver resolution, R, in the range 1000 to 40,000 over a wavelength range 370-950 nm.  Since commissioning in 2013, M2FS has been used to support over 30 distinct science projects proposed by 18 different investigators.  This project will develop multi-mode Integral Field Units for Magellan (IFU-M), to be used in conjunction with M2FS.  One key design innovation that enables this instrument is the use of fiber gangs, which handle O(10) optical fibers at once for faster fabrication and assembly.  Fabrication and assembly will take place at the PI?s lab at the University of Michigan; the completed instrument will be deployed at the Nasmyth focus of the Magellan/Clay telescope at Las Campanas Observatory, where it will undergo commissioning and use as a facility instrument.

por.por_cntn:
Astronomical spectroscopy is the tool that transforms the spectacular images of cosmic sources into detailed understanding of the nature of those sources and of the Universe as a whole.  Traditionally, astronomical spectrographs have been able to sample only a very small point of the sky or, at most, a short linear segment.  Many celestial targets, however, are extended on the sky and so it is impossible or impractical to survey them completely using such instruments. 

In recent years, ‘Integral Field Units’, or IFUs, have been developed that can obtain spectra of extended patches of the sky and allowing comprehensive studies of the chemical make-up, internal motions and stellar/gaseous content of celestial sources. The current NSF/MRI grant has been used to develop one such instrument, known as IFUM, which can deploy three IFUs to study a wide variety of astronomical sources with a broad assortment of instrumental configurations.

IFUM is now deployed at the Magellan/Clay telescope at the Las Campanas Observatory in Chile.  Uniquely, IFUM provides the means to obtain IFU data at high spectral resolution which enables detailed studies of the chemical make-up of sources and precise measures of the internal motions of the stars and gas that make up these sources.  And since IFUM is used in conjunction with a 6.5m telescope—still one of the largest in the world—it is incredibly sensitive and can explore the physical nature of very faint sources.  The bulk of the time and funding from the current grant was used to develop, design, fabricate and deploy IFUM using facilities at the Univ. of Michigan, Carnegie Observatories, and the Magellan Observatory.

 In its first year of operation, IFUM has already explore the nature of dwarf galaxies in environments that range from near the Milky Way, to systems associated with distant large galaxies, and among isolated galaxies scattered in ‘local’ intergalactic space and vast distances that are reachable only due to the power of gravitational lensing.  IFUM has also explore the gas content of nearby galaxies and its origin from supernova explosions and violent mass flows from high-mass stars.  It has also been used to study galaxies whose luminosity largely derives from mass flow onto supermassive black holes, a process IFUM can directly detect and characterize.

IFUM will become a fixture at the Magellan Observatory for years to come, undoubtedly exploring an even broader science exploration portfolio than it has already begun to tackle.  As a facility instrument at Magellan, IFUM will be available directly to the many astronomers directly associated with the Magellan Consortium, as well as to the broader US astronomical community via time-sharing programs largely sponsored by NSF.

Images (1 of )
  • IFUM is shown attached to the Magellan/Clay telescope (at right). The 1776 optical fibers deployed on the sky travel through the blue and red conduits into MSpec, a multi-fiber spectrograph developed by PI Mario Mateo (shown in this image) and funded by an early NSF/MRI grant.
    Mario Mateo/Jeb Bailey
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Mario L Mateo
    IFUM
  • This image of a compact, star-forming galaxy is based on IFUM data. This tiny, extremely faint, system is over 20 million light-years distant, yet with IFUM we see its internal rotation (red, receding gas on one side; blue approaching gas on the other) revealing an extensive Dark Matter content.
    Mario Mateo
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Mario L Mateo
    Velocity field of Distant Dwarf Galaxy
  • The wispy distribution of hot gas is visible in the image of NGC 3109, a nearby dwarf neighbor of the Milky Way. The grid shows IFUM fields obtained or planned to cover the extent of the system. The B/W image shows 180 spectra (from left to right) that reveal the motion and chemistry of this gas.
    Mario Mateo
    Public Domain
    Mario L Mateo
    IFUM Survey of a Nearby Dwarf Galaxy
  • This image shows the (nearly) raw output of IFUM observations of a star that exploded some 2000 yrs ago in the nearby Small Magellanic Cloud galaxy. The wispy features show the violent expansion of this gas--at over 1500 km/s--as traced by the oxygen produced and ejected in the explosion.
    Mario Mateo/Barry Madore
